title: Friday, 13th October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Well, hello there. Fancy seeing you here again.

BE11:03am

And it's a bit Friday 13th on the corporate news front.

BE11:04am

We got this out of the way yesterday, of course .....

11:03 am
BE11:04am

BE11:04am

Blockbuster names, together at last! The business world equivalent of Alien Vs Predator.

BE11:05am

Here's our story on that totally real thing that's absolutely going to happen: https://www.ft.com...-aab9-abaa44b1e130

11:05 am
BE11:05am

And, yes, we also had the record highs yesterday.

BE11:06am

Hey, look at this.

BE11:06am

11:06 am
BE11:06am

That's bitcoin vs FTSE 100, 1yr.

BE11:06am

They're correlating! Since mid August they're moving nearly in lockstep.

BE11:07am

... though if you normalise that graph so they both start at 100, it doesn't look quite so impressive for the FTSE.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

BE11:08am

(@Alex2005: preaching to the choir, mate: https://ftalphavil...ent-in-delta-none/ )

BE11:09am

(@Alewis: sorry!)

11:09 am
BE11:10am

So anyway, should we Brexit? We've not Brexited for a few days, and Friday is as good a day as any.

BE11:10am

Sterling tonked yesterday, levelling out a bit today.

BE11:11am

And ING's frankly sick of it.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

GBP’s whipsaw price action yesterday is indicative of the currency’s somewhat inexplicable sensitivity to Brexit-related headlines. Markets had seemingly priced in a higher probability of a ‘no deal’ Brexit as the fifth round of talks between the UK and EU concluded with the latter stating that discussions are at a ‘deadlock’. Yet, fears of a ‘hard’ Brexit were quickly reassessed – with GBP reversing its 1% fall on the day following reports that the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier is willing to offer a two-year Brexit transition deal.
None of this should be new news for GBP markets; contingency planning around a ‘no deal’
Brexit by UK officials seems logical, but in our view should not be a central scenario priced into
currency markets. At best it serves as a tail risk, keeping the extent of GBP upside potential
limited.

BE11:11am

We continue to see progressive steps towards a Brexit transition deal as being GBP supportive
via three channels – in particular via the channel of higher short-term UK rates. Indeed, expect the narrative for GBP to slowly shift towards the Nov ‘Super Thursday’ BoE meeting after next week’s EU leaders summit. Here we see upside risks as the Bank are not only likely to hike by 25bp, but the risks are that Governor Carney signals that this is more than a ‘withdrawal of stimulus’ hiking cycle.

BE11:12am

And Citi, previewing the EU Summit

11:12 am
BE11:13am

No breakdown, no progress, something in the middle? – Barnier said the “time has not come yet” for transition or future relations talks. However, he hinted towards exploring ways forward “over the next few weeks”. That suggests the EU will neither end the talks nor move beyond phase one. We expect a middle outcome: the EU27 could ask Barnier to draft a negotiating directive for transition talks.

BE11:13am

Decisions in December? – If the UK concedes further on the financial settlement and the EU offers a transition beyond March 2019 that effectively extends the status quo, the 14/15 December summit could move talks to the next phase and signal that a cliff-edge will most likely be avoided. We stress, however, that only a ratified treaty can end business uncertainty for good.

 Any help for May? – The EU27 is likely to show unity at next week’s summit again Their strong negotiating position, underpinned by diverging economic and political fortunes with the UK, has repeatedly allowed them to agree on the toughest possible position against the UK as a common denominator. However, without any positive signal, May and her new conciliatory Brexit strategy could come under more domestic pressure. The EU Withdrawal Bill is an opportunity for pro- and anti-Brexit MPs to react. A politically unstable UK is probably not in the EU’s interest.

BE11:14am

And back to FX via HSBC.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

BE11:15am

Look, I dunno. And I don't know about this drop intro either.

BE11:16am

Cycling has become one of the most popular and fastest growing sports in the UK. But it is not
just “middle-aged men in lycra” taking up two wheels. GBP has also been caught up in the
cycling buzz – albeit in a slightly different manner. The pound has been pedalling along to
cyclical drivers, while largely swerving political risks and ongoing structural frailties.
Admittedly, weaving political risk into a currency forecast is seldom easy. And it may be that the
road to Brexit is so long, winding and uncertain that the market is unwilling or unable to express
a coherent political view on the GBP. But we believe that ignoring political factors is risky.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

It keeps going.

BE11:16am

Politics is a vital cog, one the FX market has downplayed in 2017, preferring the more visible
and intuitive tracking of cyclical drivers. The cycle may have felt especially pertinent as the
market countenances a shift in monetary policy to a tightening bias from a loosening one. But
the focus on interest rate differentials is a mistake, in our view. We believe this has led to
an overly optimistic consensus for GBP-USD, and a sizable descent for the pair in 2018.
We believe the market will move through the gears and reconsider politics much more actively as
the finish line for Article 50 negotiations looms into view. One way to remove the political blinkers
is adopting a more straightforward view of a complicated situation. We coalesce the myriad
Brexit outcomes into three, ranging from “soft Brexit” to “no deal”. Each carries different
implications for GBP-USD, ranging from 1.45 down to 1.10 in our view. By attaching a
probability to each outcome, a weighted exchange rate is generated. This helps inform whether
one believes the spot FX market is under-pricing political risk or not. We believe it is.

BE11:16am

In the end, we will finish with only one outcome. Our range of possible Brexits will condense
to one. In this way, GBP will begin to behave like a European option with an expiry date of
29 March 2019. But until we reach this moment, GBP should be seen as the blend of
different probabilities of each outcome alongside a blend drivers: political and structural,
not just cyclical.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

So .. the gist -- if I can summarise the gist of that spawling extended bike analogy, which goes on for several more pages -- is that gbp's stuck in a range and politics is going to monkey with it.

BE11:19am

1) Soft Brexit: GBP-USD at 1.45
2) Smooth and stable transition: GBP-USD at 1.30-1.35
3) No deal/cliff edge: GBP-USD at 1.10

BE11:19am

So, which? Dunno.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

How to price the likelihoods? Dunno.

BE11:19am

BE11:21am

But is GBP too high given the infinite number of things that go wrong? Yeah, probably.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

The FX market is saddled with the problem of how to interpret the incredibly complicated
political drivers of GBP, and appears to be ignoring the problem, fixating on cyclical drivers
instead. Clearly the outlook for the economy, inflation and the BoE are important considerations
but the market is in danger of underplaying the vital element of political risk. By simplifying the
potential Brexit outcomes, and blending their probabilities, it becomes possible to at least get a
gauge of how divergent spot is from a given viewpoint on political risk. The market’s apparent
complacency reassures us that our pessimism on GBP is not misplaced.

BE11:21am

(@Minerve: shush. Don't let daylight into magic.)

undefined
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Okay, so that's filled sometime. What next?

BE11:22am

There's GKN.

GKN PLC (GKN:LSE): Last: 324.24, down 28.56 (-8.10%), High: 335.00, Low: 317.60, Volume: 21.40m
11:22 am
BE11:23am

Followed up all the recent speculation around a breakup with a good old-fashioned profit warning.

BE11:23am

2017 PBT will be "slightly above" 2016, whereas the consensus was aiming for £85m profit growth.

BE11:24am

So, you're looking at a 10% downgrade.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Due to two probable significant external claims in Aerospace and Driveline, on which it provides no detail whatsoever.

BE11:25am

Plus a non cash £15m inventory charge in Aerospace

BE11:25am

And even ignoring that, Aerospace looks a bit weak.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

As per UBS:

BE11:26am

Commercial Aerospace sales were marginally down in Q3 vs. our expectations of 2% y/y growth. Margins were weaker than expected on the back of pricing pressure, programme transitions and operational charges – with headwinds expected to continue in Q4. Q3 Aerospace EBIT benefited from a £20m positive pricing adjustment. GKN also announced a review of the carrying value of goodwill and other assets at the end of the year. The company is accelerating efforts to improve operational performance in North America.

BE11:27am

We're getting no detail on the two claims because of commercial sensitivity. Though I don't understand why we can't even get details on how the claims split between the two divisions, or even why there's two of them.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Here's the CEO Nigel Stein on the conference call ....

BE11:28am

I'm sorry to be springing a surprise in you, and I know the market doesn't like surprises. But that 2 unexpected potential claims hit us in the space of 24 hours was certainly a surprise to me. And after 16 years of delivering on expectations, a very
disappointing experience in my final quarter at
GKN.

Now today's announcement is about 2 things: First, very recently and on the same day this week, we became aware of 2 customer claims, which has yet to be formally advised to us, but which we judge as likely to impact on our 2017 results. One is in Aerospace, one in driveline. Unfortunately, we are bound by strict confidentiality agreements, so can't get any more details, including which customers, programs or models are concerned.

But they are of this nature and nothing to do with litigation or suchlike. The combined cost is estimated to be some GBP 40 million, which we expect to bulk in quarter 4. The cash impact could be in quarter 4 this year or, perhaps more likely, in quarter 1 2018 with a small amount thereafter.
They relate to the street events. We do not expect them to recur and are confident this charge will take care of them. And neither of them suggests
the GKN's operating processes have a fundamental problem.

BE11:31am

He was then prodded a bit about whether the aerospace claim is for the engine side of the business -- which I guess might be tied into a recent failure or something?

11:31 am
BE11:32am

But, nope. No dice. Confidentiality. Can't say more.

BE11:32am

Anyway, here's Barclays.

BE11:32am

Given the claims do not relate to litigation we assume they must relate to some past operational shortfall on quality causing re-work and, although the size may be exceptional, we view this is a recurring cost of doing business. We note in the case of Aerospace there is the chance that GKN is having to bear the cost of a quality shortfall of another company where it has a programme share, which might explain why CEO Nigel Stein commented they felt “mugged”. The cash outflow from the charges is expected to be in 4Q17 or more likely 1Q18 with small amount after. The issue does not relate to Kobe Steel which has recently admitted to providing falsely certified components to its customers.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

And .....

BE11:33am

We note there has been renewed focus on the possibility of a break-up of the business following the decision made earlier this year to partially pay down the pension and the management change announced in September. The operational challenges may increase investor pressure on the company but we note the hurdle has always been the pension, with the requirement to maintain the same level of protection for pension-holders. Following the warning we think it is fair to assume pension trustees would be arguing that the risk profile of the group has increased. However, we argue that the rationale for a break-up is stronger than in the past as the expected inflection in cash generation in the Aerospace business as R&D and capex investment comes down mean it has a greater ability to service debt (a higher debt level being required if a break-up contribution to the pension was made).

BE11:03am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with the markets and the live.

11:33 am
undefined
BE11:35am

On Pearson, no sure .............. Though there's a Q3 update due October 17 so there's plenty of previews floating around.

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 636.86, up 14.86 (+2.39%), High: 640.00, Low: 621.50, Volume: 921.05k
11:35 am
BE11:36am

Barclays, again, for instance.

BE11:36am

We expect - 7.5% organic growth in 3Q17 for NA HE Courseware, and -6.0% for the year. We believe consensus is towards the bottom end of management’s +1% to -7% FY range. But with the shares recovering a little recently, we think buyside expectations are a bit more positive. If 3Q17 growth is better, it would be a positive, even if it would not in reality be a reliable guide to future growth, given the volatility of bookstore destocking. We think Pearson’s shares do not currently look cheap in 2020E on P/E using average group organic growth between now and then of -1% and assuming it is reasonable to stack only half of management’s guided £300m of savings on to 2020E EBITA. But if 3Q17 growth is better, for a while at least, the market is likely to have more faith in a better outcome for growth and savings.

undefined
11:38 am
BE11:38am

And so, we wind closer to midday.

BE11:39am

Oh, good story from Javier.

BE11:39am

https://www.ft.com...-999d-5ea7d5fd46a6

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the US buyout group, is expected to raise up to €5bn in Europe from investors in a new flagship fund some time next year, according to several people familiar with the plans.

BE11:40am

PE's already sitting on a lot of cash. I know we always say that, but it's reasonably true at the moment.

BE11:41am

Graph from Preqin:

11:41 am
BE11:41am

BE11:42am

So, funds raising $500-600bn p.a. range for the last four years and $1,466bn on the sidelines waiting to be used.

BE11:43am

That's a hell of a lot of LBOs to come, in theory.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Lots more Toys R Us's and Monarchs. Lots more Debenhams and Game Digitals. Can't wait.

undefined
BE11:43am

Provident. Sure.

11:43 am
Provident Financial PLC (PFG:LSE): Last: 868.44, up 79.44 (+10.07%), High: 935.00, Low: 834.50, Volume: 5.42m
BE11:44am

It's not a profit warning, that's the good news.

BE11:44am

Collection rates have improved a tad, from a very low base.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

And there's a bit of colour on how they intend to fix this thing.

BE11:45am

As in, recruiting at least 300 additional "Customer Experience Managers"

BE11:46am

Plus adding a load more support staff. Twice as many regional managers, along with compliance folk, administration and arrears folk, etc.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

What doesn't change is FY guidance.

BE11:46am

Here's Goldman.

BE11:47am

Current performance in Home Credit remains consistent with the group’s previous FY17 guidance, as although the collections performance improved in September (to 65%, from 57% in August), the guidance assumes continuous improvement in collections and sales performance. The release does not provide any update on the FCA’s investigation into Vanquis Bank’s ROP product. Operating trends elsewhere within Vanquis and Moneybarn appear robust, relative to our expectations. Overall, we would not expect the information contained within today’s release to meaningfully shift the market’s current pricing of the shares. However, we note that the shares have experienced elevated volatility over recent weeks, with precise expectations (relative to current guidance) difficult to gauge.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Ande RBC.

BE11:48am

Our conclusion is that today’s statement reinforces our negative stance. The small recovery in collections should not be applauded – as this is as we anticipate and management still expects a large loss. Further, the regulatory uncertainty over Vanquis persist, while the upcoming debt repayments, likely FCA redress at Vanquis, ongoing losses, potential goodwill and intangible write-offs, and the negative impact of IFRS 9 and the stress tests on 28 Nov will result in a stretched balance sheet with the likely need for additional equity capital. In addition, PFG’s customer base (which is predominantly subprime and credit is largely unsecured) seems to be experiencing the impact of higher inflation and an uncertain economic outlook as evidenced by the company’s move to tighten underwriting standards.

BE11:50am

And SocGen.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

We maintain our TP at 1,300p (details on p.2), as we seek to take a conservative approach to Provident's earnings, ratings and potential regulatory redress payments. While the lack of CEO, the uncertainty of the timeframe of the turnaround of the Home Credit business and the ongoing regulatory investigation are all potential sources of fresh concerns, we see these risks as priced in at current levels, and thus retain our Buy rating. Key future dates are the trading updates in January 2018, any update on the regulatory investigation and the announcement of a new CEO (where Provident confirmed today that an agency has been appointed to conduct a search).

BE11:51am

Here's what that valuation breakdown looks like:

BE11:51am

11:52 am
BE11:52am

You'll notice, if you squint, the £280m for refunds/fines on its not-quite-PPI-but-not-dramatically-different-from-PPI-thing.

BE11:52am

That's ................ brave.

BE11:54am

You'll remember Barclays saying a day or two ago that Provident looks to have made more than £400m from the policies, if you roll in the interest charged on the membership fees.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

If the fine is anywhere close to that, then the October retail bonds due this year and next become a bit tight.

undefined
BE11:56am

So ........ what else?

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Talktalk. Someone's slotted a load, we don't know who.

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 205.75, down 12.25 (-5.62%), High: 206.50, Low: 201.80, Volume: 5.41m
BE11:57am

4.7% stake done at 210.5p.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

(@Penny -- yes, you are correct and I'm wrong on that.)

BE11:59am

45.1m shares. Possibly a Barclays client, as they say this this morning:

BE11:59am

We downgrade TalkTalk to Equal Weight (from Overweight). Even when rolling our price target to March 2019 (increases to 215p from 185p), we see no upside to our new price target on our current forecasts. We also do not expect the upcoming 1H results to indicate any significant change in earnings trajectory, with the company focused firmly on growing the customer base and repositioning its mobile strategy. As such, we believe upside potential could come from Fibre co-investment or Fixed- Mobile M&A optionality, which we see as unlikely any time soon.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

1H focus – We model an improving revenue (but not earnings) trajectory; EBITDA 1H:2H split expected. 1Q18 revenues (ex Carrier) were -3.2%, and we see this momentum continuing into 2Q, where we model revenues (ex Carrier) of -1%, with tailwinds from August price increases on the legacy base and lower base drag. TalkTalk has already indicated it sees a 1H:2H split of EBITDA due to the phasing of SAC/marketing investments, and hence we model 1H EBITDA of £95m, with 15k net adds (1Q: 20k). We see churn remaining low at c1.3%, ARPU improving sequentially to £27.50/mth, and look for an update on the mobile strategy now the MVNO model has been de-emphasized.

BE12:00pm

We see Fibre/Co-investment optionality, and our research has shown upside from fixed-mobile consolidation. We see fixed-mobile convergence coming, which does stretch the business models for mobile-only and fixed-only operators through higher wholesale fees, and this increases the need/likelihood for fixed-mobile mergers, in our view - BT Group PLC: Openreach CEO for a Day (01 August 2017). Openreach is now trying to establish a viable model to build fibre to the home, and is consulting key stakeholders. We would see TalkTalk as a natural partner to co-invest with Openreach in a FTTP world given it has already made initial forays into FTTP investment. We believe the economics of co-investment could also be very attractive (see body of note), boosting medium term value. The balance sheet does provide a constraint however.

BE12:00pm

PT to 215p; implies no upside. Our earnings forecasts are broadly unchanged. We estimate TalkTalk trades on 14x Mar 19E P/E, 7x EV/EBITDA and offers an 8.9%/5.1% equity FCF/DPS yield vs challenger peers on 18x, 8x. 5.8% and 4.6% respectively.

12:01 pm
undefined
BE12:03pm

Just to reiterate over this side of the page -- I was wrong above about the Provident October 2017 bond.

BE12:04pm

We don't have a means to edit these transcripts so I need to add my clarifications in realtime, which is super fun.

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

The Group’s CET 1 ratio was 21.2% at Sep-17 (vs. 21.5% at Jun-17) and gearing at 3.0x.
Total funding capacity at Sep-17 stood at £356m, which included £194m of cash, £70m
headroom on committed debt facilities and £92m of additional retail deposit capacity.
However this falls to £236m post the payment of the 2012 retail bonds paid down on 4 Oct,
which is in line with the ~£200m capacity we had estimated in our note out on 11 Oct 2017.
2018 maturities look light, in our opinion, comprising the third instalment of the M&G term
loan of £15m due in Jan-18 and £20m of private placement loan notes due in Mar-18.

BE12:05pm

That's what the structure looks like, as per Barclays.

BE12:05pm

And with that, I think we're done.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Some guy called Paul Murphy will be wirh you next week. He's buying a generator today, to allow him to work from his Mozambique beach hut.

BE12:06pm

I'm not kidding. This is really what's happening.

BE12:07pm

Watch Aggreko shares to see if there's any response to that incrementally significant new business for them.

12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

So, until next week, thanks and bye. Afternoon all.

BE11:33am

.... so, that's GKN. Or as much as we can say about GKN anyway.
